commit_message:
Docs: Configure meters/events dispatch separately

This is a docs change in support of Change-Id:
I161318f4503ce79205b54a93f2ae9b4e052f7971

Dispatchers now only record meter or event data and are configured
independently. The install guide is updated to reflect this
distinction. Because the referenced Change-Id used Doc-Impact
as a flag instead of the non-hyphenated variant there is no
independant bug in the OpenStack Manuals project for this change.

Additionally, existing content for configuring Gnocchi is broken out
into more detail.

Change-Id: I11e9a3037e8be6d0d76c41f4ddd4e94583dc132f
Related-Bug: #1480333
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/82/283282/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data can be easily sent to multiple internal and external systems. Dispatchers are divided between `event_dispatchers` and `meter_dispatchers` which can each be provided with their own set of receiving systems. .. note:: In Liberty and prior the configuration option for all data was `dispatcher` but this was changed for the Mitaka release to break out separate destination systems by type of data. Ceilometer by default only saves event and meter data in a database, to allow Ceilometer to send data to other systems in addition to the database, multiple dispatchers can be developed and enabled by modifying the Ceilometer configuration file. meter_dispatchers=database meter_dispatchers=fileone can configure the line without a dispatcher, like the following:: event_dispatchers= With the above configuration, no event dispatcher is used by the Ceilometer collector service, all event data received by Ceilometer collector will be dropped. meter_dispatchers = gnocchi [dispatcher_gnocchi] archive_policy = low The value specified for archive_policy should correspond to the name of an archive_policy configured within Gnocchi. For Gnocchi dispatcher backed by Swift storage, the following additional configuration settings should be added::
deleted_lines: metering data can be easily sent to multiple internal and external systems. Ceilometer by default only saves metering data in a database, to allow Ceilometer to send metering data to other systems in addition to the database, multiple dispatchers can be developed and enabled by modifying Ceilometer configuration file. dispatcher=database dispatcher=file .. note:: dispatcher is in [collector] section in Havana release, but it is deprecated in Icehouse.one can configure the line like the following:: dispatcher= With above configuration, no dispatcher is used by the Ceilometer collector service, all metering data received by Ceilometer collector will be dropped. dispatcher = gnocchi archive_policy = low url = http://localhost:8041 The `url` in the above configuration is a Gnocchi endpoint url and depends on your deployment.

Refactor node update operation in cluster action

This patch refactors the node-update action creation code in cluster
action module to use the 'create' method from the Action module.

commit_message:
Refactor node create operation in cluster action

This patch refactors the action creation code in cluster action when
creating new nodes. These operations will use the 'create' method from
the Action module.

Change-Id: Ic806e7c0c38fab9baf4d45e56a8eeca3dd88ae63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/62/285862/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(base_action.Action, 'create') mock_node, mock_index, mock_action, mock_update, mock_load): mock_action.return_value = 'NODE_ACTION_ID' mock_action.assert_called_once_with(action.context, 'NODE_ID', 'NODE_CREATE', action.context, 'NODE_ACTION_ID', {'status': base_action.Action.READY}) @mock.patch.object(base_action.Action, 'create') mock_node, mock_index, mock_action, mock_update, mock_load): mock_action.side_effect = ['NODE_ACTION_1', 'NODE_ACTION_2'] mock.call(action.context, 'NODE_ACTION_1', {'status': 'READY'}), mock.call(action.context, 'NODE_ACTION_2', {'status': 'READY'})
deleted_lines: mock_node, mock_index, mock_update, mock_load): n_action = mock.Mock() n_action.id = 'NODE_ACTION_ID' mock_action = self.patchobject(base_action, 'Action', return_value=n_action) mock_action.assert_called_once_with('NODE_ID', 'NODE_CREATE', user=self.ctx.user, project=self.ctx.project, domain=self.ctx.domain, action.context, n_action.id, {'status': n_action.READY}) mock_node, mock_index, mock_update, mock_load): node_action_1 = mock.Mock() node_action_2 = mock.Mock() mock_action = self.patchobject( base_action, 'Action', side_effect=[node_action_1, node_action_2]) mock.call(action.context, node_action_1.id, {'status': node_action_1.READY}), mock.call(action.context, node_action_2.id, {'status': node_action_2.READY})

commit_message:
Adding index to stack.owner_id

Performance fix- Adding an index to stack.owner_id
to avoid full table scan as done before the fix

Closes-Bug: #1535051

Change-Id: Ib0e17917aeeb4af8603bc090f0740783cf41f42f
Signed-off-by: Tomer Shtilman <tomer.shtilman@nokia.com>

commit_message:
Mock time.sleep() in 3 unit tests

No need to actually wait in unit tests. This patch decreases the unit
tests run time by about 24 seconds.

Change-Id: I502e15e0fd2d8238f6b6b7089eb38d4d7b55114b

Refactor webhook trigger operation

This patch refactors the webhook-trigger operation to use the 'create'
method from the Action module.

Change-Id: I8f24c5f60271383c2d468d4926b713d44e96226a

commit_message:
Fix cluster status_reason setting when actions failed

There are cases where the create/update/delete actions failed but the
cluster status_reason is not properly set. This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Ief266969c612465a3889e2c5101e24fa4f50b046
Closes-Bug: #1545963

commit_message:
Enable cluster registry and health check in Health Manager

This patch is for semi-automation scenatio of health management.

Implements: blueprint support-health-management-customization

Change-Id: Ib8b00c2069f651ecb9568b88e111bbc9028c6ac2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/99/282299/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. ''' Health Manager class. Health Manager is responsible for monitoring the health of the clusters and take corresponding actions to recover the clusters based on the pre-defined health policies. ''' import mock from senlin.common import consts from senlin.common import context as senlin_ctx from senlin.common import messaging as rpc_messaging from senlin.db.sqlalchemy import api as db_api from senlin.engine import cluster as cluster_mod from senlin.engine import health_manager from senlin.tests.unit.common import base class TestHealthManager(base.SenlinTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestHealthManager, self).setUp() mock_eng = mock.Mock() mock_tg = mock.Mock() mock_eng.engine_id = '1234' topic = consts.ENGINE_HEALTH_MGR_TOPIC version = consts.RPC_API_VERSION self.hm = health_manager.Health_Manager(mock_eng, topic, version, mock_tg) def test_init(self): self.assertEqual('1234', self.hm.engine_id) self.assertIsNotNone(self.hm.threadgroup) self.assertEqual(consts.ENGINE_HEALTH_MGR_TOPIC, self.hm.topic) self.assertEqual(consts.RPC_API_VERSION, self.hm.version) self.assertEqual(0.5, self.hm.periodic_recover_threshold) self.assertEqual(60, self.hm.periodic_interval_max) self.assertEqual(True, self.hm.periodic_enable) self.assertEqual(60, self.hm.periodic_fuzzy_delay) @mock.patch.object(senlin_ctx, 'get_service_context') def test__build_context(self, mock_get_service_ctx): service_cred = { 'auth_url': 'AUTH_URL', 'username': 'senlin', 'user_domain_name': 'default', 'password': '123', 'project': None } ctx = mock.Mock() mock_from_dict = self.patchobject(senlin_ctx.RequestContext, 'from_dict', return_value=ctx) mock_get_service_ctx.return_value = service_cred res = self.hm._build_context() self.assertEqual(ctx, res) mock_get_service_ctx.assert_called_once_with() mock_from_dict.assert_called_once_with(service_cred) def test_periodic_tasks(self): ctx = mock.Mock() self.hm._build_context = mock.Mock(return_value=ctx) cluster = mock.Mock() cluster.id = 'CLUSTER_ID' cluster.get = mock.Mock(return_value='project1') node = mock.Mock() node.status = 'ACTIVE' cluster.nodes = [node] mock_get_clu = self.patchobject(db_api, 'cluster_get_all', return_value=[cluster]) mock_load = self.patchobject(cluster_mod.Cluster, 'load', return_value=cluster) self.hm.rpc_client = mock.Mock() mock_check = self.patchobject(self.hm.rpc_client, 'cluster_check', return_value=mock.Mock()) mock_recover = self.patchobject(self.hm.rpc_client, 'cluster_recover', return_value=mock.Mock()) self.hm.periodic_tasks() mock_get_clu.assert_called_once_with(ctx, filters=None, limit=None, marker=None, project_safe=False, sort=None) mock_load.assert_called_once_with(ctx, cluster_id='CLUSTER_ID') mock_check.assert_called_once_with(ctx, 'CLUSTER_ID') node.status = 'ERROR' self.hm.periodic_tasks() mock_recover.assert_called_once_with(ctx, 'CLUSTER_ID') @mock.patch('senlin.rpc.client.EngineClient') @mock.patch('oslo_messaging.Target') def test_start(self, mock_target, mock_ct): target = mock.Mock() mock_target.return_value = target rpc_server = mock.Mock() mock_st = self.patchobject(rpc_messaging, 'get_rpc_server', return_value=rpc_server) mock_add_tm = self.patchobject(self.hm.threadgroup, 'add_timer', return_value=mock.Mock()) self.hm.start() mock_target.assert_called_once_with(server='1234', topic='engine-health-mgr', version='1.0') mock_st.assert_called_once_with(target, self.hm) rpc_server.start.assert_called_once_with() mock_add_tm.assert_called_once_with(self.hm.periodic_interval_max, self.hm.periodic_tasks)

Remove event logs in lbaas driver

This patch removes event logs in lbaas driver since they are
unnecessary.

Change-Id: I62ced316fa60bb2280a339eb07105420525aeacb

'software deployment delete', 'stack abandon', 'stack check', 'stack output list', 'stack resume', 'stack show', 'stack snapshot list', 'stack suspend', 'stack template show', 'stack update-cancel' ] for cmd in cmds: err = self.assertRaises(exceptions.CommandFailed, self.openstack, cmd + ' I-AM-NOT-FOUND') self.assertIn('not found', str(err)) help_text = self.openstack('help stack list') lines = list ' 'heat_template_version.2015-10-15') tmpl_functions = self.parser.listing(ret) self.assertTableStruct(tmpl_functions, ['functions', 'description']) def test_openstack_resource_type_list(self): in parms: cmd += ' --parameter ' + parm ret = self.openstack(cmd) self.assertRegexpMatches(ret, r'stack_name.*|.*test_stack') def test_heat_template_validate_yaml(self): self._template_validate( 'heat_minimal.yaml', ['ClientName=ClientName', 'WaitSecs=123'] ) def test_heat_template_validate_hot(self): self._template_validate( 'heat_minimal_hot.yaml', ['test_client_name=test_client_name', commit_message:
Fixes minor issues

Fix some word spellings in messages.
Do not log twice with different level.
config options: use nova.conf.
Remove unused CONF imports.
Remove unused logging import and LOG global var.
Add transitional support for migrate data objects.

Change-Id: I34006a82c134398f17512de7e7b6c52980460521

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Removes pointless check in livemigrationops

Support for Windows / Hyper-V Server 2008 R2 has been deprecated in
Liberty and it is no longer supported in Mitaka.

This was missed in the previous commit:
I1ec83f852d23758bc91da8fd8021b1bed34c63b3

Co-Authored-By: Andrei Bacos <abacos@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Change-Id: I389364a9111b7b115991b31798a4c32268c90dda
Related-Bug: #1508066

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Trace original exception before converting exception

Reraising an exception causes the original traceback to be lost.
Logging the original trace before reraising will help greatly in
debugging.

Reraises nova Exception while maintaining the original traceback.

Change-Id: I247bcd22a8c26b947f523cfd33d9f97184eb52a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv refs/changes/25/284225/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys def test_assert_original_traceback_maintained(self): def bar(self): foo = "foofoo" raise os_win_exc.HyperVVMNotFoundException(vm_name=foo) self.driver._vmops.get_info.side_effect = bar try: self.driver.get_info(mock.sentinel.instance) self.fail("Test expected exception, but it was not raised.") except exception.InstanceNotFound: # exception has been raised as expected. _, _, trace = sys.exc_info() while trace.tb_next: # iterate until the original exception source, bar. trace = trace.tb_next # original frame will contain the 'foo' variable. self.assertEqual('foofoo', trace.tb_frame.f_locals['foo'])

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 10:41:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/25524dc208c45d20dba39a3989bd4ff6cd848b77', 'message': 'Fix race condition in RemoteFS create_snapshot_online

commit_message:
Fix race condition in RemoteFS create_snapshot_online

There's a `while True` loop in create_snapshot_online and each
iteration can make the `cinder-volume` process sleep up to 10sec. In
the mean time, if Nova fails to create the snapshot, the snapshot
status could turn to "error" and someone could want to delete the
erroneous snapshot, which would make its status to be "deleting".

In that case the `while True` loop would never exit. Cinder consumes
100% of CPU and keeps logging "Status of snapshot XX is now deleting".

The patch fix this issue by exiting the `while True` loop if we detect
that the snapshot is to be deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1538496

Change-Id: I5de0e8479a552ce101cecd06a874a170e54d5c18
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/53/281753/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Perhaps a concurrent ' 'request was made.') % {'id': snapshot['id']} raise exception.RemoteFSConcurrentRequest(msg)
deleted_lines: LOG.debug('Status of snapshot %(id)s is now %(status)s', {'id': snapshot['id'], 'status': s['status']})

commit_message:
cleanup of operator requirements network design doc

rewrote some of the paragraphs and sentences
removed extra spaces where necessary
changed needs to need - removed plural
capitalized Internet
removed unnecessary words from sentences

Change-Id: I138253a9ea48263c9d5f6f2b0f10c80c608ab88e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/59/284759/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: the interconnect needs within the cluster, plus the need to allow clients to access their resources, and for operators to access the cluster for maintenance. The bandwidth, latency, and reliability of these networks need to be considered. Whether you are using an external provider or an internal team, additional design decisions about monitoring and alarming need to be made. If you are using an external provider, service level agreements (SLAs) likely apply with your contract. In addition, other operational considerations such as bandwidth, latency, and jitter can be part of the service level agreement. As demand for network resources increase, consider the ability to upgrade the infrastructure. Operators add additional IP address blocks and add additional bandwidth capacity. In addition, consider managing hardware and software lifecycle events, for example upgrades, decommissioning, and outages, while avoiding service interruptions for tenants.for services that require direct client access from the Internet. UponAdditionally, consider how to respond to network events. How load transfers from one link to another during a failure scenario could be a factor in the design. If you do not plan network capacity correctly, failover traffic could overwhelm other ports or network links and create a cascading failure scenario. In this case, traffic that fails over to one link overwhelms that link and then moves to the subsequent links until all network traffic stops.
deleted_lines: the interconnect needs within the cluster, plus the need to allow clients to access their resources, and for operators to access the cluster for maintenance. The bandwidth, latency, and reliability of these networks needs consideration. Make additional design decisions about monitoring and alarming. This can be an internal responsibility or the responsibility of the external provider. In the case of using an external provider, service level agreements (SLAs) likely apply. In addition, other operational considerations such as bandwidth, latency, and jitter can be part of an SLA. Consider the ability to upgrade the infrastructure. As demand for network resources increase, operators add additional IP address blocks and add additional bandwidth capacity. In addition, consider managing hardware and software lifecycle events, for example upgrades, decommissioning, and outages, while avoiding service interruptions for tenants.for services that require direct client access from the internet. UponAdditionally, consider how to respond to network events. As an example, how load transfers from one link to another during a failure scenario could be a factor in the design. If you do not plan network capacity correctly, failover traffic could overwhelm other ports or network links and create a cascading failure scenario. In this case, traffic that fails over to one link overwhelms that link and then moves to the subsequent links until all network traffic stops.

commit_message:
Check for device node availability before mkfs

When using the generic driver, a volume is attached to the service
VM and then a mkfs is done to create a FS on that volume inside of
the VM. But it can be the case that it takes a bit of time before
the device node pops up inside of the VM. So wait some seconds
before doing a mkfs on a non-existing device node.

Change-Id: I42228d9a8ad836a95be5c59e43bd6762677dd85f
Closes-bug: #1547000

commit_message:
Remove unneeded revocation events

Instad of revoking upon Project deactivat ion and so on
this does a live check upon token validation.

Some of the role apis are a little more forgiving.

If a user loses a role, it is ipoosible that the token will
still validate, just with a lesser set of roles.  However,
if the role removed is the last role, the tokek will still
be invalid.

Trustee pass word change no longer invalidates a token. It
never should have, as the Trustee is not involved during
trust execution.

Change-Id: Ifb71829a3bcc16a6c6a4776fc25dc742cb574f1b

added_lines: _NAMES = ['audit_id', 'user_id']_EVENT_NAMES = _NAMES 'user_id': ['user_id', 'trustee_id'], # For other fields we try to get any branch that concur # with any alternative field in the token. for alt_name in ALTERNATIVES.get(name, [name]): yield token_data[alt_name] 'expires_at','user_id', 'trustee_id'
deleted_lines: _NAMES = ['trust_id', 'consumer_id', 'access_token_id', 'audit_id', 'domain_id', 'project_id', 'user_id', 'role_id']_EVENT_NAMES = _NAMES + ['domain_scope_id'] 'trustor_id', 'user_id': ['user_id', 'trustor_id', 'trustee_id'], 'domain_id': ['identity_domain_id', 'assignment_domain_id'], # For a domain-scoped token, the domain is in assignment_domain_id. 'domain_scope_id': ['assignment_domain_id', ], if self.domain_id and self.expires_at: # This is revoking a domain-scoped token. self.domain_scope_id = self.domain_id self.domain_id = None else: # This is revoking all tokens for a domain. self.domain_scope_id = None 'role_id', 'domain_id', 'domain_scope_id', 'project_id', if self.trust_id is not None: event['OS-TRUST:trust_id'] = self.trust_id if self.consumer_id is not None: event['OS-OAUTH1:consumer_id'] = self.consumer_id if self.consumer_id is not None: event['OS-OAUTH1:access_token_id'] = self.access_token_id if name == 'role_id': # Roles are very special since a token has a list of them. # If the revocation event matches any one of them, # revoke the token. for role_id in token_data.get('roles', []): yield role_id else: # For other fields we try to get any branch that concur # with any alternative field in the token. for alt_name in ALTERNATIVES.get(name, [name]): yield token_data[alt_name] 'expires_at','user_id', 'project_id', 'identity_domain_id', 'assignment_domain_id', 'trust_id', 'trustor_id', 'trustee_id' 'consumer_id', 'access_token_id' project = token_data.get('tenant') if project is not None: token_values['project_id'] = project['id'] else: token_values['project_id'] = None token_values['identity_domain_id'] = default_domain_id token_values['assignment_domain_id'] = default_domain_id token_values['trust_id'] = None token_values['trustor_id'] = None token_values['trust_id'] = trust['id'] token_values['trustor_id'] = trust['trustor_id'] token_values['consumer_id'] = None token_values['access_token_id'] = None role_list = [] # Roles are by ID in metadata and by name in the user section roles = access.get('metadata', {}).get('roles', []) for role in roles: role_list.append(role) token_values['roles'] = role_list # Federated users do not have a domain, be defensive and get the user # domain set to None in the federated user case. token_values['identity_domain_id'] = user.get('domain', {}).get('id') token_values['identity_domain_id'] = None project = token_data.get('project', token_data.get('tenant')) if project is not None: token_values['project_id'] = project['id'] token_values['assignment_domain_id'] = project['domain']['id'] else: token_values['project_id'] = None domain = token_data.get('domain') if domain is not None: token_values['assignment_domain_id'] = domain['id'] else: token_values['assignment_domain_id'] = None role_list = [] roles = token_data.get('roles') if roles is not None: for role in roles: role_list.append(role['id']) token_values['roles'] = role_list token_values['trust_id'] = None token_values['trustor_id'] = None token_values['trust_id'] = trust['id'] token_values['trustor_id'] = trust['trustor_user']['id'] oauth1 = token_data.get('OS-OAUTH1') if oauth1 is None: token_values['consumer_id'] = None token_values['access_token_id'] = None else: token_values['consumer_id'] = oauth1['consumer_id'] token_values['access_token_id'] = oauth1['access_token_id']

commit_message:
Sanity check for cinder

This runs first sanity check for cinder. Once
cinder is deployed it checks volumes.list()

Change-Id: I1b4cc57f21cf0fa52a391229c2c2b3fa995d32a8
Partially-Implements: blueprint sanity-check-container
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/09/285609/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - name: Cinder sanity checks command: docker exec -t kolla_toolbox /usr/bin/ansible localhost -m kolla_sanity -a "service=cinder project=service user=admin password={{ cinder_keystone_password }} role=admin region_name={{ openstack_region_name }} auth={{ '{{ openstack_cinder_auth }}' }}" -e "{'openstack_cinder_auth':{{ openstack_cinder_auth }}}" register: cinder_sanity changed_when: "{{ cinder_sanity.stdout.find('localhost | SUCCESS => ') != -1 and (cinder_sanity.stdout.split('localhost | SUCCESS => ')[1]|from_json).changed }}" until: cinder_sanity.stdout.split()[2] == 'SUCCESS' retries: 10 delay: 5 run_once: True when: kolla_enable_sanity_cinder | bool

commit_message:
Update OSC metavars

OpenstackClient has a consistent pattern for the metavars on their
arguments. Heatclient's plugin should follow that pattern.

Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient

Change-Id: Ie2fdb2a985c4c41235916f0745138ea9c812b4ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/14/281514/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'config', metavar='<config>', for config_id in args.config: 'total': len(args.config)}) metavar='<limit>', metavar='<id>', metavar='<config-name>', metavar='<config-file>', metavar='<destination-file>', metavar='<group>', 'config', metavar='<config>', return _show_config(heat_client, config_id=parsed_args.config,
deleted_lines: 'id', metavar='<ID>', for config_id in args.id: 'total': len(args.id)}) metavar='<LIMIT>', metavar='<ID>', metavar='<CONFIG_NAME>', metavar='<FILE or URL>', metavar='<FILE or URL>', metavar='<GROUP_NAME>', 'id', metavar='<ID>', return _show_config(heat_client, config_id=parsed_args.id,

commit_message:
Remove py33 from tox envlist

Current infra team don't run python3.3 jobs, so
need remove py33 support.

Change-Id: I736b6a677645c72bc5194b49d9951310568ce375

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-22 17:14:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/2aca7ab9e9026543bbc16b86a11ad8d522a0887a', 'message': 'Allow static methods to detect calls on object

Static methods can be called both on on class instance
and on the type object. With this refactoring it is now
possible in Python static/class methods to distinguish
which way it was called and in case of instance call
get the instance.

This commit also reworks ResourceManager to use new
functionality. Now all ResourceManager methods
are static so no class instance is necessary. If resources
belonging to some other type are required it is possible
to provide the type object explicitly to each method.
However it is still possible to create ResourceManager
instance and call statics as a normal methods. In this
case they will recognize it and will operate that were
captured at class construction. Thus it is still possible
to create ResourceManager at one place and pass it to
another class in another package so that it will access
resources of the package where the instance was created
rather than that where it used.

commit_message:
Allow static methods to detect calls on object

Static methods can be called both on on class instance
and on the type object. With this refactoring it is now
possible in Python static/class methods to distinguish
which way it was called and in case of instance call
get the instance.

This commit also reworks ResourceManager to use new
functionality. Now all ResourceManager methods
are static so no class instance is necessary. If resources
belonging to some other type are required it is possible
to provide the type object explicitly to each method.
However it is still possible to create ResourceManager
instance and call statics as a normal methods. In this
case they will recognize it and will operate that were
captured at class construction. Thus it is still possible
to create ResourceManager at one place and pass it to
another class in another package so that it will access
resources of the package where the instance was created
rather than that where it used.

Change-Id: Ib47be86a99eb7903f7d3f7e1c5f2570df819c2d8

commit_message:
Fix BaseException.message deprecation warnings

message attribute in Exception has been deprecated since python 2.6,
and was removed in Python 3. Use encodeutils.exception_to_unicode to
convert an exception as we did in other places.

Change-Id: Ie066da8f62ba2367814e030760f5e99c7b3127ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/18/285718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: exc_message = encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(exc) {'task_id': self.task_id, 'exc': exc_message})
deleted_lines: {'task_id': self.task_id, 'exc': exc.message})

commit_message:
Add OVS vhost-user specific options for OVS agent

Neutron supports using Open vSwitch + DPDK vhost-user interfaces directly
in the OVS ML2 driver and agent. Add required options

Change-Id: Iac42128eeb3ba22ca3f4e12787fcb9cdb6d44bdc

added_lines: # [*datapath_type*] # (optional) Datapath type for ovs bridges # Defaults to $::os_service_default # # [*vhostuser_socket_dir*] # (optional) The vhost-user socket directory for OVS # Defaults to $::os_service_default # $datapath_type = $::os_service_default, $vhostuser_socket_dir = $::os_service_default, 'ovs/datapath_type': value => $datapath_type; 'ovs/vhostuser_socket_dir': value => $vhostuser_socket_dir;

commit_message:
Add support for CPU pinning in Nova

vcpu_pin_set option allows to specify a list or range of physical CPU cores
to reserve for virtual machine processes

Change-Id: If967c4dd5c45cdfc2e402b67b563f770747222e5

commit_message:
Recommend vagrant and heat for development only

Vagrant and Heat, while really cool tech, are not very well maintained
in Kolla. They are not always up to date, and as a result, are not
recommended for evaluation purposes by this change.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ic8b8519431ed5c50a9a46b2e8b8f822d0982b1cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/56/284856/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Two virtualized development environment options are available for Kolla. These options permit the development of Kolla without disrupting the host operating system. If developing Kolla on an OpenStack cloud environment that supports Heat, follow the :doc:`Heat developer environment guide <heat-dev-env>`. If developing Kolla on a system that provides VirtualBox or Libvirt in addition to Vagrant, use the Vagrant virtual environment documented in :doc:`Vagrant developer environment guide <vagrant-dev-env>`. If evaluating Kolla, the community strongly recommends using bare-metal or a VM to emulate bare-metal during the evaluation period. Follow the instructions in this document to get started with deploying OpenStack on bare-metal with Kolla.
deleted_lines: Two virtualized evaluation and development environment options are available. These options permit the evaluation of Kolla without disrupting the host operating system. If developing or evaluating Kolla on an OpenStack cloud environment that supports Heat, follow the :doc:`Heat evaluation and developer environment guide <heat-dev-env>`. If developing or evaluating Kolla on a system that provides VirtualBox or Libvirt in addition to Vagrant, use the Vagrant virtual environment documented in :doc:`Vagrant evaluation and developer environment guide <vagrant-dev-env>`. If evaluating or deploying OpenStack on bare-metal with Kolla, follow the instructions in this document to get started.

subject: Add timeout to requests.get() in kolla/cmd/build.py
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-23 22:47:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/46642bdb54f01fc01faee333e4bfb19a8e477fe2', 'message': "Add timeout to requests.get() in kolla/cmd/build.py

When kolla-build is running, if there are network issues or if the
source's location (like http://tarballs.openstack.org) fails to
respond due to high number of concurrent requests, kolla-build just
hangs/blocks indefinitely.

This patch set resolves this issue by adding a timeout of 120
seconds for requests.get() in kolla/cmd/build.py.

Change-Id: I7c8745a20b9bd1c3f5d6a55c72a794f16fd7e513
Closes-Bug:1548614

commit_message:
Add timeout to requests.get() in kolla/cmd/build.py

When kolla-build is running, if there are network issues or if the
source's location (like http://tarballs.openstack.org) fails to
respond due to high number of concurrent requests, kolla-build just
hangs/blocks indefinitely.

This patch set resolves this issue by adding a timeout of 120
seconds for requests.get() in kolla/cmd/build.py, adds a unit test
for it in kolla/tests/test_build.py and also the "timeout" argument
in kolla/common/config.py.

Change-Id: I7c8745a20b9bd1c3f5d6a55c72a794f16fd7e513
Closes-Bug: #1548614

deleted_lines: r = requests.get(source['source'])

commit_message:
Import of static and classmethod Python methods

Now not only static methods can be defined in YAML
but also in Python using standard @staticmethod
or @classmethod decorators.

Change-Id: I8a1a9bb6cf5331f225efcd1ab8abbc7b186fb882

Due to the fact that now GLARE uses separate endpoint for access [1],
all requests in muranoclient should be updated.

commit_message:
Ensure to use exception per status code for all cases

Previously, only when an exception has a content with
{'NeutronError': {'type': xxxx, 'message': xxxx}},
exception per status code is raised from neutronclient library.
There are cases where this kind of message is not contained
in exception messages, for example, some extension is loaded.

Library users expect an exception is raised based on response
status code and it should not depend on an exception message.
This commit applies a fallback logic to map generic per-status
exception to all exception types from the neutron server.

Closes-Bug: #1513879
Change-Id: Ib3d0a8359aed444b12217b3404d40443d61fc2c0

commit_message:
Fix HNAS iSCSI driver attachment

Currently, the HNAS iSCSI driver returns the logical unit number
related to the iSCSI target as a string while initializing the
connection.
This is breaking the attachment feature because os-brick expects
a numeric type.
This patch converts the LUN from string to int in order to solve
this problem.

Change-Id: I33958a93a6261b7d77e4becafa3efd5180e5d091
Closes-Bug: 1549375

commit_message:
Add an update interval to compute discovery

This option allows to collect nova-api resource not on every polling.
It's useful for the fast polling of the created instances and allow
to reduce nova-api requests count.

Change-Id: I0d163f83287a4f2ce065d3e1d930c92b1addef35
Partially-implements: improve-nova-instance-metering

commit_message:
Stop ignoring _ as builtin in pep8

We already moved to oslo.i18n and no longer implicitly use _ translating
function. It's time to remove it from pep8 ignores.

Change-Id: Ie2ee8052b8551c219de69901042e383f563358bd

commit_message:
A proposal about distributed cache for notification agents

Change-Id: Ibda449f220ab9ca9a66c6dd9e7ecd4042b4cfa58
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/telemetry-specs refs/changes/78/250778/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Make transformer cache not pipeline-specific ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+spec/common-transformer-cache Currently in Ceilometer we have a complex architecture to make notification-agent scalable. You may find more here [1]. The main reason why we cannot just run several notification agents is per-pipeline cache in transformers. To be more precise, not all transformers use cache, mostly conversions ones: [2]. If we make cached values shared between transformers, we will get scalable notification agent without additional complexity as IPC queues and partition coordination. Problem description =================== To make notification agent scalable the following were done: * We have two types of queue listeners: main (listen for notification.info) and internal (listen for IPC queues) * A batch of IPC queues were introduced * All running notification agents should be coordinated between each other (using tooz) to know the set of topics to listen to (using the internal listener) * A complex schema of IPC topics naming was introduced (grouping_keys) All the items above were done only for one purpose: to ensure that transformer stage works correctly, i.e. previously processed metric values are available for transformation along with the newest one. For example, we want to calculate a rate for metric X based on x1 and x2 notifications. We run two notification agents (without partitioning enabled). Consider the case when x1 goes to the first and x2 goes to the second. In this situation we cannot calculate the rate because x1 was cached inside the first notification agent and the second one cannot see this information. Proposed change =============== Use distributed cache. We may consider several option: Redis, Memcache. It will allow to get rid of additional queues and coordination in general for notification agents. Note that for central and alarm evaluation (aodh-related service) services coordination process remains required for scalability. Alternatives ------------ Keep it as it is now. Data model impact ----------------- No REST API impact --------------- No Security impact --------------- No Pipeline impact --------------- * IPC queues become redundant * pipeline_processing_queues config is obsolete * grouping key for transformers is obsolete * Pipeline initialisation will be changed. We may refuse from 'workload_partitioning' parameter for notification agent Other end user impact --------------------- No Performance/Scalability Impacts ------------------------------- Should be investigated. The main question to consider: read/writes operations with a distributed cache TBD Other deployer impact --------------------- A distributed cache should be installed. Note, if Ceilometer is used in coordination mode, Redis (Memcache or other) has been already installed. Developer impact ---------------- The code becomes simpler. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <nadya> Ongoing maintainer: <nadya> Work Items ---------- TBD Future lifecycle ================ No Dependencies ============ Depends on the libraries which will be used for work with the chosen cache provider (Redis, Mongo, memcache). TBD: add specific ones Testing ======= The current test base will be used. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation should be updated. References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/199331/5/specs/liberty/distributed-coordinated-notifications.rst [2] https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/transformer/conversions.py

commit_message:
XenAPI: Fix disk_formats verified by tempest

lib/glance restricts the disk_formats to those supported by XenAPI, so
tempest needs a similar restriction for the disk_formats tested.

Confirmed as passing internal Citrix CI (affected tempest jobs are
currently disabled in voting XenServer CI until this change lands)

Conflicts:
        lib/tempest

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to this line being in lib/tempest
twice:

iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG image-feature-enabled deactivate_image True

The duplication is removed so this is the same as master now.

Change-Id: Iefa5b16a3fa1789ed583426ea47ebb22e6cb571e
(cherry picked from commit 2dd761b16950603555409e33ac63a196eefd2607)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/86/284786/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ "$VIRT_DRIVER" = "xenserver" ]; then iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG image disk_formats "ami,ari,aki,vhd,raw,iso" fi
deleted_lines: iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG image-feature-enabled deactivate_image true

commit_message:
Add OSC plugin for openstack cluster build info

This change implements the "openstack cluster build info" command
  Based on the existing senlin command: senlin build-info

Change-Id: I18f5f79c15b7ebbdfe00c4d88c2b687a742d2056
Blueprint: senlin-support-python-openstackclient
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/35/285735/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Clustering v1 build_info action implementations""" import logging import six from cliff import show from openstackclient.common import utils from senlinclient.common import utils as senlin_utils class BuildInfo(show.ShowOne): """Retrieve build information.""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".BuildInfo") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(BuildInfo, self).get_parser(prog_name) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)", parsed_args) senlin_client = self.app.client_manager.clustering result = senlin_client.get_build_info() formatters = { 'api': senlin_utils.json_formatter, 'engine': senlin_utils.json_formatter, } columns = list(six.iterkeys(result)) return columns, utils.get_dict_properties(result.to_dict(), columns, formatters=formatters)

commit_message:
Resource Quota - Introduce Quota Table

Introduce Quota Table and Quota list/create API's. With
this concept it will be possible to set quota on a
resource within a project. Fox example X number
of bay creation within a project and if the request
exceeds X bay creation will not be allowed. This change
only introduces the db layer changes.

Change-Id: I8990052df48bdbf6eee426e88ed6c9c2f8cfd344
Partially-Implements: bp resource-quota

""" quotas = get_test_quotas(**kw) # Let DB generate ID if it isn't specified explicitly if 'id' not in kw: del quotas['id'] dbapi = db_api.get_instance() return dbapi.create_quotas(quotas)

commit_message:
Add OSC plugin for openstack cluster action show

This change implements the "openstack cluster action show" command
  Based on the existing senlin command: senlin action-show

Change-Id: Ia5341c5a3c996a2ff2ab6d4af4da1d412bea0366
Blueprint: senlin-support-python-openstackclient
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/53/285653/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sixfrom cliff import show from openstack import exceptions as sdk_exc from openstackclient.common import exceptions as exc class ShowAction(show.ShowOne): """Show detailed info about the specified action.""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ShowAction") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ShowAction, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( 'action', metavar='<action>', help=_('Name or ID of the action to show the details for') ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)", parsed_args) senlin_client = self.app.client_manager.clustering try: action = senlin_client.get_action(parsed_args.action) except sdk_exc.ResourceNotFound: raise exc.CommandError(_('Action not found: %s') % parsed_args.action) formatters = { 'inputs': senlin_utils.json_formatter, 'outputs': senlin_utils.json_formatter, 'metadata': senlin_utils.json_formatter, 'data': senlin_utils.json_formatter, 'depends_on': senlin_utils.list_formatter, 'depended_by': senlin_utils.list_formatter, } columns = list(six.iterkeys(action)) return columns, utils.get_dict_properties(action.to_dict(), columns, formatters=formatters)

subject: Raise ConflictError like other transport errors
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-19 12:21:05.000000000', 'files': ['zaqarclient/tests/queues/subscriptions.py', 'zaqarclient/transport/http.py', 'zaqarclient/queues/v2/core.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient/commit/8c7ae9299c1c2643ca93b2508aee6cba17f78913', 'message': "Raise ConflictError like other transport errors

Problem: errors.ConflictError for 409 error response code is raised only
in the code that is handling subscriptions:
zaqarclient/queues/v2/core.py#L130.
But the recent patch (https://review.openstack.org/274537) made Zaqar
produce 409 error responses also on operations with Pools.
So now it's better to raise errors.ConflictError in http.py where other
error response exceptions are risen:
zaqarclient/transport/http.py#L30

The patch moves raise of errors.ConflictError to
zaqarclient/transport/http.py.

Change-Id: Id9d2a006329d7a3af0489b9890553a43f0ce9152
Closes-Bug: 1542799
"}]
commit_message:
Raise ConflictError like other transport errors

Problem: errors.ConflictError for 409 error response code is raised only
in the code that is handling subscriptions:
zaqarclient/queues/v2/core.py#L130.
But the recent patch (https://review.openstack.org/274537) made Zaqar
produce 409 error responses also on operations with Pools.
So now it's better to raise errors.ConflictError in http.py where other
error response exceptions are risen:
zaqarclient/transport/http.py#L30

The patch moves raise of errors.ConflictError to
zaqarclient/transport/http.py.

Change-Id: Id9d2a006329d7a3af0489b9890553a43f0ce9152
Closes-Bug: 1542799
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/06/282306/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revise Health Policy for Health Management

This patch is to enable Health Policy and make it serve for health
management purpose.

Implements: blueprint support-health-management-customization

Change-Id: Ie2a9798547d41f1b83114c2b4ffed602b8a8e5c5

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from senlin.common import consts from senlin.common import context as senlin_context from senlin.db.sqlalchemy import api as db_api from senlin.engine import health_manager from senlin.policies import health_policy from senlin.tests.unit.common import base from senlin.tests.unit.common import utils class TestHealthPolicy(base.SenlinTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestHealthPolicy, self).setUp() self.context = utils.dummy_context() self.spec = { 'type': 'senlin.policy.health', 'version': '1.0', 'properties': { 'detection': { 'type': 'NODE_STATUS_POLLING', 'options': { 'interval': 60 } }, 'recovery': { 'fencing': ['COMPUTE'], 'actions': ['REBUILD'] } } } cluster = mock.Mock() cluster.id = 'CLUSTER_ID' node = mock.Mock() node.status = 'ACTIVE' cluster.nodes = [node] self.cluster = cluster self.patch('senlin.rpc.client.EngineClient') self.hp = health_policy.HealthPolicy('test-policy', self.spec) def test_policy_init(self): self.assertIsNone(self.hp.id) self.assertEqual('test-policy', self.hp.name) self.assertEqual('senlin.policy.health-1.0', self.hp.type) self.assertEqual('NODE_STATUS_POLLING', self.hp.check_type) self.assertEqual(60, self.hp.interval) self.assertEqual(['REBUILD'], self.hp.recover_actions) @mock.patch.object(health_manager, 'register') @mock.patch.object(db_api, 'registry_create') @mock.patch.object(senlin_context, 'get_service_context') def test_attach(self, mock_ctx, mock_reg_create, mock_hm_reg): ctx = mock.Mock() mock_ctx.return_value = ctx policy_data = { 'HealthPolicy': { 'data': { 'check_type': self.hp.check_type, 'interval': self.hp.interval}, 'version': '1.0' } } res, data = self.hp.attach(self.cluster) self.assertTrue(res) self.assertEqual(policy_data, data) mock_reg_create.assert_called_once_with(ctx, check_type=self.hp.check_type, cluster_id=self.cluster.id, engine_id=None, interval=self.hp.interval, params={}) mock_hm_reg.assert_called_once_with('CLUSTER_ID') @mock.patch.object(health_manager, 'unregister') @mock.patch.object(db_api, 'registry_delete') @mock.patch.object(senlin_context, 'get_service_context') def test_detach(self, mock_ctx, mock_reg_delete, mock_hm_reg): ctx = mock.Mock() mock_ctx.return_value = ctx res, data = self.hp.detach(self.cluster) self.assertTrue(res) self.assertEqual('', data) mock_reg_delete.assert_called_once_with(ctx, 'CLUSTER_ID') mock_hm_reg.assert_called_once_with('CLUSTER_ID') def test_pre_op(self): action = mock.Mock() action.context = 'action_context' action.data = {} action.action = consts.CLUSTER_RECOVER res = self.hp.pre_op(self.cluster.id, action) self.assertTrue(res) data = {'health': {'recover_action': 'REBUILD'}} self.assertEqual(data, action.data) def test_post_op(self): action = mock.Mock() res = self.hp.post_op(self.cluster.id, action) self.assertTrue(res) @mock.patch.object(senlin_context, 'get_service_context') def test_health_check(self, mock_ctx): ctx = mock.Mock() mock_ctx.return_value = ctx mock_check = self.patchobject(self.hp.rpc_client, 'cluster_check', return_value=mock.Mock()) self.hp.health_check(self.cluster) mock_check.assert_called_once_with(ctx, 'CLUSTER_ID') @mock.patch.object(senlin_context, 'get_service_context') def test_health_recover(self, mock_ctx): ctx = mock.Mock() mock_ctx.return_value = ctx mock_recover = self.patchobject(self.hp.rpc_client, 'cluster_recover', return_value=mock.Mock()) self.cluster.nodes[0].status = 'ERROR' self.hp.health_recover(self.cluster, 0.5) mock_recover.assert_called_once_with(ctx, 'CLUSTER_ID')

It would be better if Zaqar could provide descriptions in it's 404 and
409 error response bodies.

Reasons:

1. RFC 7231 asks to do it:
   https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.5

commit_message:
Add description to 404 and 409 error responses

It would be better if Zaqar could provide descriptions in it's 404 and
409 error response bodies.

Reasons:

1. RFC 7231 asks to do it:
   https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-6.5
2. Sometimes it might be hard for the user to figure out why Zaqar
   returns 409 response code without description in response body.
3. Zaqar already provides descriptions in these error responses:
   400 401 403 500 503 406
4. Keystone project is a good example of a project, which includes info
   in 404 responses. We can follow this example.

This patch makes it so.

Change-Id: I0d5c5b73498a40b5ec949ceb74f9bb7dcf925009
Closes-Bug: 1547258

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-senlinclient refs/changes/52/285652/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
# Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Clustering v1 action implementations""" import logging from cliff import lister from openstackclient.common import utils from senlinclient.common.i18n import _ from senlinclient.common import utils as senlin_utils class ListAction(lister.Lister): """List actions.""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ListAction") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ListAction, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( '--filters', metavar='<key1=value1;key2=value2...>', help=_("Filter parameters to apply on returned actions. " "This can be specified multiple times, or once with " "parameters separated by a semicolon. The valid filter " "keys are: ['name', 'target', 'action', 'status']"), action='append' ) parser.add_argument( '--sort', metavar='<key:dir>', help=_("Sorting option which is a string containing a list of " "keys separated by commas. Each key can be optionally " "appended by a sort direction (:asc or :desc). The valid " "sort keys are: ['name', 'target', 'action', 'created_at'," " 'status']") ) parser.add_argument( '--limit', metavar='<limit>', help=_('Limit the number of actions returned') ) parser.add_argument( '--marker', metavar='<id>', help=_('Only return actions that appear after the given node ID') ) parser.add_argument( '--full-id', default=False, action="store_true", help=_('Print full IDs in list') ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)", parsed_args) senlin_client = self.app.client_manager.clustering columns = ['id', 'name', 'action', 'status', 'target', 'depends_on', 'depended_by', 'created_at'] queries = { 'sort': parsed_args.sort, 'limit': parsed_args.limit, 'marker': parsed_args.marker, } if parsed_args.filters: queries.update(senlin_utils.format_parameters(parsed_args.filters)) actions = senlin_client.actions(**queries) formatters = {} if parsed_args.full_id: f_depon = lambda x: '
'.join(a for a in x) f_depby = lambda x: '
'.join(a for a in x) formatters['depends_on'] = f_depon formatters['depended_by'] = f_depby else: formatters['id'] = lambda x: x[:8] formatters['target'] = lambda x: x[:8] f_depon = lambda x: '
'.join(a[:8] for a in x) f_depby = lambda x: '
'.join(a[:8] for a in x) formatters['depends_on'] = f_depon formatters['depended_by'] = f_depby return ( columns, (utils.get_item_properties(a, columns, formatters=formatters) for a in actions) )

commit_message:
Spliting update_by_agent to smaller functions

Aim of this is to by able to replace meta disks part, by new version
from multipath solution. As we don't change other parts of message
format.

Change-Id: I730448a77509c284afdbe69861c3a15a75eea504
Blueprint: multipath-disks-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/04/280604/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __update_status(cls, instance, data): @classmethod def __update_ip(cls, instance, data): @classmethod def __update_disk_meta(cls, instance, data): meta = data.get('meta', {}) # don't update volume information, if agent has sent an empty array if len(meta.get('disks', [])) == 0 and instance.meta.get('disks'): logger.warning( u'Node {0} has received an empty disks array - ' u'volume information will not be updated'.format( instance.human_readable_name ) ) meta['disks'] = instance.meta['disks'] # don't update volume information, if it is locked by node status if 'disks' in meta and cls.hardware_info_locked(instance): logger.debug("Volume information is locked for update on node %s", instance.human_readable_name) meta['disks'] = instance.meta['disks'] @classmethod def update_by_agent(cls, instance, data): """Update Node instance with some specific cases for agent. * don't update provisioning or error state back to discover * don't update volume information if disks arrays is empty :param data: dictionary of key-value pairs as object fields :returns: Node instance """ # don't update provisioning and error back to discover cls.__update_status(instance, data) cls.__update_disk_meta(instance, data) cls.__update_ip(instance, data)
deleted_lines: def update_by_agent(cls, instance, data): """Update Node instance with some specific cases for agent. * don't update provisioning or error state back to discover * don't update volume information if disks arrays is empty :param data: dictionary of key-value pairs as object fields :returns: Node instance """ meta = data.get('meta', {}) # don't update volume information, if agent has sent an empty array if len(meta.get('disks', [])) == 0 and instance.meta.get('disks'): logger.warning( u'Node {0} has received an empty disks array - ' u'volume information will not be updated'.format( instance.human_readable_name ) ) meta['disks'] = instance.meta['disks'] # don't update volume information, if it is locked by node status if 'disks' in meta and cls.hardware_info_locked(instance): logger.debug("Volume information is locked for update on node %s", instance.human_readable_name) meta['disks'] = instance.meta['disks']

commit_message:
Sending parsed info to nailgun without interpretation

Agent will now send parsed info for every block device to nailgun
and for dmsetup_info once. Nailgun will now process all information
that is provided. This removes most of disk logic/interpretation
on nailgun-agent side.

Blueprint: #fc-multipath-packages
Depends-on: Iae165f73fd7f83cd27431ec5e3d4b66098b0731a
Change-Id: I28ec9e6a723315a8f52f1c7b75a19c98b53c57c3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-nailgun-agent refs/changes/44/277744/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dname = bname.gsub(/!/, '/') # 512 bytes is the size of one sector by default block_size = 512 fn = "/sys/block/#{bname}/queue/logical_block_size" block_size = File.read(fn).to_i if File.exist? fn block_size = 512 if block_size == 0 @logger.debug("Trying to find out if device #{devname} is removable or not") if File.exists?("/sys/block/#{basename_dir}/removable") removable = File.open("/sys/block/#{basename_dir}/removable"){ |f| f.read_nonblock(1024).strip } @logger.debug("Device #{devname} removable parameter: #{removable.inspect}") detailed_meta[:disks] << { :size => (binfo[:size].to_i * block_size), :udev_info => `udevadm info --query=all --name=#{bname}`, :removable => removable }
deleted_lines: if physical_data_storage_devices.map{|d| d[:name]}.include?(bname) && binfo @logger.debug("Block device seems to be physical data storage: #{bname}") block = physical_data_storage_devices.select{|d| d[:name] == bname}[0] if block[:removable] =~ /^1$/ && ! REMOVABLE_VENDORS.include?(binfo[:vendor]) pci_vendor_id = _get_pci_vendor_id(bname) @logger.debug("Block device #{bname} is removable. PCI vendor ID: #{pci_vendor_id}") unless REMOVABLE_PCI_VENDORS.include?(pci_vendor_id) next end @logger.debug("Block device #{bname} is accepted by PCI vendor ID") end dname = bname.gsub(/!/, '/') # 512 bytes is the size of one sector by default block_size = 512 fn = "/sys/block/#{bname}/queue/logical_block_size" block_size = File.read(fn).to_i if File.exist? fn block_size = 512 if block_size == 0 detailed_meta[:disks] << { :name => dname, :model => binfo[:model], :size => (binfo[:size].to_i * block_size), :disk => block[:disk], :extra => block[:extra], :removable => block[:removable] } def _disk_id_by_name(name) dn = "/dev/disk/by-id" basepath = Dir["#{dn}/**?"].select{|f| /\/#{name}$/.match(File.readlink(f))} basepath.map{|p| p.split("/")[2..-1].join("/")} end def _disk_path_by_name(name) dn = "/dev/disk/by-path" basepath = Dir["#{dn}/**?"].find{|f| /\/#{name}$/.match(File.readlink(f))} basepath.split("/")[2..-1].join("/") if basepath end def physical_data_storage_devices @blocks ||= [] return @blocks unless @blocks.empty? @logger.debug("Trying to get list of physical devices") raise "Path /sys/block does not exist" unless File.exists?("/sys/block") mds, devices = _find_fake_raid_mds() Dir["/sys/block/*"].each do |block_device_dir| basename_dir = File.basename(block_device_dir) # Entries in /sys/block for cciss look like cciss!c0d1 while # the entries in /dev look like /dev/cciss/c0d1. udevadm uses # the entry in /dev so we need to replace the ! to get a valid # device name. devname = basename_dir.gsub(/!/, '/') # Skipping MD if it's a container. Also skipping underlying # devices from which that container is composed. next if devices.include?("/dev/#{devname}") next if devname.start_with?('md') and not mds.include?(devname) @logger.debug("Getting udev properties for device: #{devname}") properties = `udevadm info --query=property --export --name=#{devname}`.split("\n").inject({}) do |result, raw_propety| key, value = raw_propety.split(/\=/) result.update(key.strip => value.strip.chomp("'").reverse.chomp("'").reverse) end @logger.debug("Device #{devname} udev properties: #{properties.inspect}") @logger.debug("Trying to find out if device #{devname} is removable or not") if File.exists?("/sys/block/#{basename_dir}/removable") removable = File.open("/sys/block/#{basename_dir}/removable"){ |f| f.read_nonblock(1024).strip } end @logger.debug("Device #{devname} removable parameter: #{removable.inspect}") if STORAGE_CODES.include?(properties['MAJOR'].to_i) @logger.debug("Device #{devname} seems to be appropriate") # Exclude LVM volumes (in CentOS - 253, in Ubuntu - 252) using additional check unless properties['DEVPATH'].include?('virtual/block/dm') @blocks << { :name => basename_dir, :disk => _disk_path_by_name(devname) || devname, :extra => _disk_id_by_name(devname) || [], :removable => removable, } end end end @logger.debug("Final list of physical devices is: #{@blocks.inspect}") @blocks end

commit_message:
Make consistent wording

This commit makes them to have consistency. Originally, there are some
variations such as Passes/Passed, Success, Failures/Failed,
% Failures/Failure %/%Failed, etc.
In this commit, they are Passes, Failures, % Failures.

Change-Id: I5f9d392cb25738e88594531641c1d3e24100ecfa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/86/282186/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <th sort-field="passes">Passes</th> <th sort-field="failures">Failures</th> <th sort-default sort-field="failuresRate">% Failures</th>
deleted_lines: <th sort-field="passes">Passed</th> <th sort-field="failures">Failed</th> <th sort-default sort-field="failuresRate">% Failed</th>

commit_message:
Huawei: Don't fail when port group does not exist

Currently when we request a port group but the
port group does not exist, an error will be raised.
This is not appropriate, because port group not
exists is a normal case.

Closes-Bug: #1536040
Change-Id: I0614163574dac384167ce2bce8887f674f3a97b5

Add `Manage Polices` row action for cluster

Now we could attach policies for cluster

Change-Id: I5587fbad26cea8f6dfe63e457795d50f1db0e70c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin-dashboard refs/changes/41/285341/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from django.core.urlresolvers import reversefrom senlin_dashboard.cluster.clusters.tables import AttachedPoliciesTable class ManagePoliciesView(tables.DataTableView, forms.ModalFormView): table_class = AttachedPoliciesTable form_class = clusters_forms.ManagePoliciesForm form_id = "manage_policies" modal_header = _("Manage Policies") modal_id = "manage_policies" template_name = 'cluster/clusters/manage_policies.html' submit_url = "horizon:cluster:clusters:manage_policies" success_url = reverse_lazy("horizon:cluster:clusters:index") page_title = _("Manage Policies") def get_data(self): policies = senlin.cluster_policy_list( self.request, self.kwargs['cluster_id'], {}) return policies def get_context_data(self, **kwargs): context = super(ManagePoliciesView, self).get_context_data(**kwargs) args = (self.kwargs['cluster_id'],) context['submit_url'] = reverse(self.submit_url, args=args) context['form'] = self.get_form() return context def get_initial(self): return {'cluster_id': self.kwargs['cluster_id']} def get(self, request, *args, **kwargs): # Table action handling handled = self.construct_tables() if handled: return handled return self.render_to_response(self.get_context_data(**kwargs)) @memoized.memoized_method def get_form(self, **kwargs): form_class = kwargs.get('form_class', self.get_form_class()) return super(ManagePoliciesView, self).get_form(form_class) def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs): form = self.get_form() if form.is_valid(): return self.form_valid(form) else: return self.get(request, *args, **kwargs)

commit_message:
Remove 'verbose' from faafo.conf and update sample config file

The parameter 'verbose' is deprectaed and will be removed in a future
release of oslo.config.

Change-Id: I66c9443f2fd9ce4566c07ea5915815f700fb1fa7

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-27 02:55:02.000000000', 'files': ['senlin/drivers/openstack/sdk.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/senlin/commit/0b7252bcc576108ebc04129cd38ac34331290604', 'message': 'Fix SDK exception parsing

There are cases where the exceptions returned from services are not
correctly parsed by either keystoneauth1 or python-openstacksdk.
Fortunately, the sdk code kept the original response instance where we
can parse the content to extract a more precise/useful message.

Change-Id: Ied68ac3b5d6b75cab6bd72ff944d302aca6c3585
Closes-Bug: #1515108
'}]
commit_message:
Fix SDK exception parsing

There are cases where the exceptions returned from services are not
correctly parsed by either keystoneauth1 or python-openstacksdk.
Fortunately, the sdk code kept the original response instance where we
can parse the content to extract a more precise/useful message.

Change-Id: Ied68ac3b5d6b75cab6bd72ff944d302aca6c3585
Closes-Bug: #1515108

commit_message:
Add "--filter" for command openstack cluster profile list

1. This change added "--filter" for profile list osc command.
2. It updated the metavar in file profile.py

Add OSC plugin for openstack cluster receiver list

This change implements the "openstack cluster receiver list" command
  Based on the existing senlin command: senlin receiver-list
